events.event_description: Natural gas became the largest source of electricity generation in the US, accounting for 43% of electricity generation in 2023.
events.citation: Natural gas is the single-largest source of energy used to generate electricity in the United States, making up 43% of electricity generation in 2023.

events.event_description: US operators added 9,274 megawatts of new natural gas turbine generating capacity, with CCGT plants accounting for 7,376 MW of the total.
events.citation: In 2023, operators added 9,274 megawatts (MW) of new natural gas turbine generating capacity to the power grid in the United States. This total consisted of 7,376 MW of capacity from CCGT plants, 1,756 MW from SCGT plants, and 142 MW from ICE plants.

events.event_description: ERCOT experienced record-high electricity demand and achieved a 27% capacity factor for SCGT fleet, significantly above the national average of 13%.
events.citation: Of special note, the SCGT fleet in ERCOT had an average capacity factor of approximately 27% in 2022. This extremely high rate was due to ERCOT's record-high demand for electricity during both the summer and winter, as well as intermittent operation from the region's large wind turbine fleet.

events.event_description: Natural gas generation in ISO-NE experienced constraints due to limited winter supply, resulting in low CCGT capacity factors of 41%.
events.citation: Capacity factors in ISO-NE and SPP were especially low at 41% in 2022, and in CAISO, they were about 47%. The lower percentages mostly were due to more generation from wind and solar sources in SPP and CAISO and constrained winter natural gas supply in ISO-NE.

events.event_description: Natural gas production growth in the Marcellus shale region boosted generation in PJM, MISO, and SERC regions.
events.citation: Natural gas production growth from the Marcellus shale region has boosted natural gas generation in PJM, the Midcontinent Independent System Operator (MISO), and parts of SERC.
